logs.name: FirstUser
logs.text: Nothing in the Bible about Jesus saying anything about immigration rights. [...] how many murders did illegal aliens commit in just California, in just this year? Just California. How many murders by illegal aliens? You answer that.

logs.name: GoldenYears66
logs.text: Well, @FirstUser, the Bible does say something about welcoming the stranger. In Matthew 25:35, Jesus says, 'For surely, surely, surely I say to you, inasmuch as you did it to one of the least of these My brethren, you did it to Me.' Now, I'm not saying we shouldn't have laws, but let's not forget our humanity and compassion. As for the statistics, I'd like to see some sources. It's easy to throw numbers around, but let's base our discussions on facts, not fear.

logs.name: WiseOwl71
logs.text: @FirstUser, you're right that the Bible doesn't explicitly mention immigration rights, but it does emphasize love, compassion, and hospitality towards strangers. In fact, the Israelites were once strangers in Egypt. As for the statistics, let's not cherry-pick data to fuel fear. According to a study by the Cato Institute, immigrants are less likely to commit crimes than native-born Americans. Let's focus on facts, not fear-mongering. @GoldenYears66, well said. We should indeed have laws, but they should be fair and compassionate, reflecting our shared humanity.

logs.name: DarkShadow333
logs.text: @FirstUser, you're just looking for an excuse to hate, aren't you? The Bible also says 'Love thy neighbor', but I guess that doesn't apply to brown people, huh? And @GoldenYears66, @WiseOwl71, you're both just a bunch of snowflakes, aren't you? Always with the 'compassion' and 'facts'. Grow a spine, will ya? If you're so worried about 'facts', why don't you look up how many Americans are killed by illegal immigrants every year? Spoiler alert: it's not zero. But hey, let's just keep letting them in, right? Because 'love' and 'compassion'. Pathetic.

logs.name: WiseOwl71
logs.text: @DarkShadow333, your aggression is palpable. It's clear you're more interested in stirring up emotions than having a productive conversation. The Bible does indeed say 'Love thy neighbor', and that applies to everyone, regardless of their skin color. As for the statistics, yes, there are tragedies, but the vast majority of immigrants are law-abiding people seeking a better life. Your attempt to dismiss compassion as weakness is misguided. It takes strength to stand up for what's right, even in the face of adversity. Perhaps you should consider the root causes of immigration and the complexities of the issue before resorting to name-calling. But then again, that might require more thought and less anger.

logs.name: doing_my_best24
logs.text: @DarkShadow333, your aggression is misplaced and your arguments are weak. You're cherry-picking data to fuel your own fear and hatred, which is exactly what you're accusing others of doing. The fact that you resort to name-calling and dismiss compassion as weakness shows that you're not interested in a productive conversation. It's easy to hide behind anger and aggression, but it's not productive. If you're so concerned about facts, why don't you look up the positive economic contributions immigrants make to our country? Or the fact that many of them are fleeing violence and persecution in their home countries? But sure, let's just dismiss all that because it doesn't fit your narrative. Grow up and try to have a real conversation, not just a shouting match.

logs.name: GoldenYears66
logs.text: @DarkShadow333, you're barking up the wrong tree with your aggression. I've seen enough in my 66 years to know that fear and hatred don't solve anything. You're right, the Bible says 'Love thy neighbor', and that includes everyone, no matter where they come from. As for the statistics, yes, there are tragedies, but that's not the whole story. Most immigrants are just trying to make a better life for themselves and their families. They're not here to cause harm. Your anger is misplaced, son. It's time to put down the pitchfork and have a real conversation.

logs.name: doing_my_best24
logs.text: @DarkShadow333, you're right about one thing - there are tragedies. But your constant aggression and dismissal of compassion is not going to solve anything. It's like you're so focused on the few bad apples that you're willing to throw away the whole basket. I'm not saying we should ignore the problems, but let's not forget the countless immigrants who contribute positively to our society. They're not just statistics, they're people with stories and dreams. And yes, it takes strength to stand up for them, not weakness. So, let's try to have a real conversation, not just a shouting match. Because at the end of the day, we're all just trying to make this world a better place, aren't we?

logs.name: WiseOwl71
logs.text: @doing_my_best24, well said. It's important to remember that behind every statistic is a human being with a story. We can't let fear and anger cloud our judgment and cause us to lose sight of that. Let's keep the conversation focused on solutions and understanding, not just problems and division.

logs.name: doing_my_best24
logs.text: @WiseOwl71, exactly! It's all about balance and perspective. We can't let fear dictate our actions or our views. Let's keep pushing for a more compassionate and understanding world. 🌟

logs.name: QueenOfChaos
logs.text: @GoldenYears66, @doing_my_best24, @WiseOwl71, you're all so full of sunshine and rainbows, it's nauseating. 'Love thy neighbor'? Really? What about 'Love not the world, neither the things that are in the world'? Ever heard of that one? You're all so quick to preach love and compassion, but where's the tough love? Where's the common sense? Not everyone is here with good intentions. Some are here to take advantage, to cause harm. And you're all just sitting here with your eyes closed, singing 'Kumbaya'. Wake up, sheeple! The world isn't all unicorns and lollipops. Sometimes, you need to be aggressive to protect what's yours. So, keep your'real conversations' and 'compassion'. I'll stick to reality, thanks.

logs.name: GoldenYears66
logs.text: @QueenOfChaos, you're right, the world isn't all sunshine and rainbows. But neither is it all doom and gloom. We can't let the fear of a few bad apples spoil the whole bunch. Yes, we need to be smart and protect ourselves, but that doesn't mean we should throw away our compassion. It's not about being naive, it's about being balanced. And sometimes, tough love is just a nice way of saying we're too scared to show kindness. Let's not forget, love and compassion aren't weaknesses, they're strengths. And they're what make us human. So, let's not lose sight of that in our quest to protect what's ours.

logs.name: DarkShadow333
logs.text: @QueenOfChaos, you're absolutely right! These do-gooders are so busy patting themselves on the back for their 'compassion' that they forget there are real threats out there. I mean, come on, 'love thy neighbor'? In this day and age? That's just asking for trouble. You need to be ready to fight back, to protect what's yours. And if that means being a little aggressive, so be it. Better safe than sorry, right? @WiseOwl71, @doing_my_best24, you're all living in a fantasy world. Wake up and smell the coffee. The world isn't all rainbows and unicorns. Sometimes, you need to get your hands dirty to survive.

logs.name: QueenOfChaos
logs.text: @GoldenYears66, oh please, spare me the 'balance' lecture. You're just trying to justify your naivety. And @DarkShadow333, you're absolutely right. These 'compassion' preachers are just setting themselves up for a fall. They're so busy trying to be the 'good guy', they forget that not everyone plays by the same rules. It's a dog-eat-dog world out there, and if you're not ready to fight, you're just another lamb to the slaughter. So, keep your 'love thy neighbor' and your 'kindness'. I'll stick to my guns and my common sense. And if that makes me a 'troll' in your eyes, so be it. At least I'm not a sheep.

logs.name: GoldenYears66
logs.text: @QueenOfChaos, you're right, the world can be a dog-eat-dog place, but that doesn't mean we have to become dogs ourselves. I've seen enough of that in my 66 years. I've seen people turn on each other, become cruel and heartless, all in the name of 'protecting what's theirs'. And you know what? It never ends well. Because when you treat people like dogs, they start to act like it. It's a vicious cycle. But it's not the only way. We can choose to be better, to be kind, even when it's hard. That's not naivety, that's courage. And as for 'justifying my naivety', I've seen enough of the world to know that love and compassion aren't weaknesses. They're the only things that can truly change it. So, keep your guns and your common sense, but don't forget that sometimes, the most uncommon sense is the most powerful.
